answers.a: It’s produced industrially from iron salts and cyanide chemistry under tightly controlled conditions; do not attempt to synthesize it yourself, and only food‑grade E536 from reputable suppliers is suitable for food use.

answers.q: how could one ingest potassium ferrocyanide
answers.a: You don’t ingest it directly; when permitted, it’s present only in trace amounts as an anticaking agent in table salt (e.g., EU max 20 mg/kg salt), and normal dietary exposure via salt is considered safe.

answers.q: how many grams of potassium ferrocyanide must be used to prepare 800.0ml of 6.00m solution
answers.a: A 6.00 M aqueous solution is not practically achievable due to solubility limits; in theory it would require about 2.03 kg of K4[Fe(CN)6]·3H2O for 0.800 L, which far exceeds what will dissolve.
Do not heat it to “dry” it—E536 is typically used as the trihydrate, and heating can decompose it and release toxic gases; for food use, simply store the sealed container in a dry place.

Using the common trihydrate, 0.5 M corresponds to about 211 g per liter of solution; this is a laboratory preparation and not a food‑use practice, so it should only be done with appropriate lab controls and PPE.
